column1: [1] [P-Reference Area-N] | Most common treatment types are lagoons and activated sludge

[2] [P-Reference Area-S] | Results of a study in 111 towns: 84 wastewater treatment plants in use in study area (waste stabilization ponds, Imhoff tanks, anaerobic reactors, filters, septic tanks, constructed wetlands, mixed treatment); severe problems with functionality and efectiveness of treatment plants.
[3] [P-Adjustment-S] | Data for 82 cities (year 2003): 80 treatment facilities (treated volume: 0.048 km3/year).
[5] [P-Observations-N] | 1106 treatment facillities including 883 from cities and 323 from peri-urban area.
[6] [P-Reference Area-S] | in 2002: 218 municipalities have wastewater treatment plants.
[7] [P-Adjustment-S] | In 2003: Data for 43 cities: 33 treatment facilities (treated volume: 4.168 m3/s).
[8] [P-Reference Area-S] | Applied treatment types: Anaerobic reactors, aerated lagoones, facultative lagoones, anaeorobic lagoones, septic tanks.

[9] [P-Reference Area-S] | Information on applied treatment types is taken from source 98, p. 3. Neither indication of corresponding year, nor information on source of information that was used. Indicated publication year of the country report (source 98).

[10] [P-Reference Area-S] | Treatment processes mainly based on primary and secundary treatment. 23 plants operated by the Corporacion de Acueductos y Alcantarillados de Santo Domingo (CAASD); their capacity is of 64 960m3/day to cover a population of 408 500 inhabitants.
[11] [P-Adjustment-S] | In 2003: In cities Babahoyo and Baba (82 100 inhab.): 2 treatment facilities (treated volume: 0.178 m3/s).
[12] [P-Reference Area-S] | 11 of 262 municipalities have a wastewater treatment plant available; sedimentation systems and biological filters prevail with 64% of all treatment types.
[13] [P-Reference Area-S] | In 2012, existent treatment plants constitute of waste stabilisation ponds.
[14] [P-Reference Area-N] | Out of 129 treatment plants, 51 are activated sludge, 41 facultative and 33 aerated

[15] [P-Reference Area-N] | The municipal wastewater is mostly treated in sedimentation ponds to a primary level.  No treatment at secondary and tertiary level, except for Islamabad and Karachi that have a biological treatment system.

[16] [P-Adjustment-S] | In 2003: Data for cities San Lorenzo, Lambare, Pedro J. Caballero, Coronel Oviedo, Caaguazu, Limpio, Villarrica, Caacupe, San Bernadino (624 400 inhab.):  9 treatment facilities (treated volume: 0.1 m3/s).
[18] [P-Reference Area-S] | Existent treatment plants constitute of waste stabilisation ponds. Additionally there are two ponds in process.

[19] [P-Reference Area-S] | Treatment level: 2.1% primary, 97.9% secundary treatment (92% of facilities are different types of waste stabilisation ponds, with facultative lagoones being the most implemented (78% of all treatment plants)).
[20] [P-Reference Area-S] | The Peruvian state currently plans the contruction of two treatment plants of capacities of 14 m3/s and 6.3 m3/s, to treat municipal residuals from Lima.
[21] [P-Comparability (over time)-N] | Source does not specify the reason for fluctuation in treatment plant numbers
[22] [P-Observations-N] | Does not take into account South Carolina and the Northern Mariana Islands
